messages.subject: Re: [UnschoolingDiscussion] what unschooling looks like
messages.msgSnippet: ... WHEW! That was close! I was sure after I read my post that I would make one of your lists!  : )  I m a work in progress.  I appreciate your comments
messages.messageBody:
>
> *****Go easy on "literally."
> Your statement doesn't quite qualify for my collection (which might be
> a
> relief to you, but look at these, and realize that "all" and "never"
> are not
> likely conditions.
>
WHEW! That was close! I was sure after I read my post that I would make
one of your lists! : ) I'm a work in progress. I appreciate your
comments greatly.
>
>
> *******And here's something about what unschooling doesn't look like:
> http://sandradodd.com/seeingit
>

I hadn't read this before. Very cool! I read it to my son and he said
"yeah, now get off my back!" (with a smile on his face). He's such a
sweety.

> ******How many waking hours are in a year? Don't ask your child to
> figure it out;
> you figure it out. And keep it to yourself. And try to stop counting.
>

Oh man! I didn't know I was going to have to do math today! How
ironic that it came from an unschooling veteran. heehee I couldn't
make my son answer it! He pretty much does what he wants.

I'll try to stop counting. That will be tough to do until I figure a
way around the whole "logging hours" issue

Faith
>
>
>

messages.subject: what unschooling looks like
messages.msgSnippet: In a message dated 1/30/05 6:41:47 PM, kbcdlovejo@aol.com writes:
messages.messageBody:
In a message dated 1/30/05 6:41:47 PM, kbcdlovejo@... writes:

<< I try to

>let him unschool, but he literally wants to do nothing but play Halo 2

>or other games. >>

Go easy on "literally."
Your statement doesn't quite qualify for my collection (which might be a
relief to you, but look at these, and realize that "all" and "never" are not
likely conditions.

http://sandradodd.com/strew/ifilet

And here's something about what unschooling doesn't look like:
http://sandradodd.com/seeingit

-=-Some of it I count towards his

>1000 hours, but I find I have to give him little nudges to fill in the

>hours. Â -=-

How many waking hours are in a year? Don't ask your child to figure it out;
you figure it out. And keep it to yourself. And try to stop counting.

Sandra

Sandra
